Report.name: AGE-WELL's Project Scorecard and Reporting Framework

ReportSection.name: Overview
ReportSection.title: AGE-WELL's Project Scorecard and Reporting Framework
ReportSection.ReportItem: {$item}

The objectives of the NCE program are to mobilize multi-disciplinary research capacity from across Canada, engage partners from multiple academic institutions and various public and private-sector organizations, train the next generation of highly qualified people, work with end users to accelerate the creation and application of new knowledge as well as increase collaboration between research in Canada and abroad.

The aim of the form is to allow the RMC to assess the progress, performance against the key impact objectives of AGE-WELL and demonstrate that the network is effectively working to achieve our goals. Reporting is crucial to the ongoing success and future of AGE-WELL.

AGE-WELL produces products (technologies, services and policy) that MUST have impact. Progress towards achieving these products can be defined and measured across all projects in a consistent fashion. The Product Readiness Levels (PRL) is a method of estimating maturity and progress towards a product across a 9 point scale. It is based on the Technology Readiness Levels (TRL), which is a well-established approach in engineering and other fields. It has been adapted for use in AGE-WELL in order to be inclusive of the different types of products and research that our members conduct. Part of this adaptation has been adopting a modified scale that maps the original 9 TRL levels into 5 stages. AGE-WELL has adapted both scales to be inclusive of the types of projects and products that are part of the Network. Please refer to the Product Readiness Levels Guideline table for definitions of the PRL levels, as well as example outputs at each level across product type. Note that the current outputs in this table are only examples and will be added to as we continue to roll out this process, and we receive feedback from members of AGE-WELL.

Projects are required to justify the current PRL stage they are at, and which stage they will be at one year later. It is expected that projects will progress through theses stages at an appropriate pace, in order to receive ongoing investment however it should be noted that it is expected that some projects may remain at a specific PRL longer than others. Justification and a demonstration of progress is required.

Each project is required to complete 2 tables related to the 5 NCE objectives (Scientific Excellence, Transdisciplinary Working, Networking and Partnerships, Knowledge Mobilization, Commercialization and HQP Training) for the past year and for the upcoming year. All projects are asked to complete the tables relevant to their project; not all projects may be able to complete both the KM and Commercialization tables. These tables will be used by the RMC to create a Balance Scorecard to determine the progress projects are making across the TRL continuum each year. The outcome of RMC review of each project will be used to make a recommendation to the AGE-WELL Board of Directors with respect to ongoing funding levels and continuation of projects.

The report consists of qualitative and quantitative information to appropriately capture the progress your project is making on the key impact area.

The report requests three types of information:

  1. Narrative- a short written account of what the project has been doing to achieve impact;
  2. Metrics- quantitative data (most values are auto populated via reporting on Forum) substantiating information must be provided for all entered values; and
  3. Case study (optional)- a short vignette that describes an outstanding work or achievement by the project.

For more information on the development of this evaluation or instructions please watch the Webinar posted on the Intranet. You can also find a Word version of the form here if you would like to work offline.

ReportSection.name: Assessment & Readiness
ReportSection.title: Project Assessment and Readiness Level
ReportSection.ReportItem: Projects can be at different stages of product readiness, from concept to deployment and adoption. Please refer to the guidelines in order to define which stage best characterises your project.

ReportItem.options: Technology product - a device or system that someone will buy or adopt|Policy/practice product - information that will be used by stakeholder or end-user, including others in the network|Service product - a service or information product that will be used by another entity

ReportSection.ReportItem:
Product Description

What kind of product(s) are you developing (check all that apply):

{$item}

Describe the outcome of your project and the potential added value of what you have completed over the past year.

{$item}

Product Development

AGE-WELL is expected to deliver significant economic benefits through new products, enterprises, improved services and the net monetary value of improved health and independence of seniors and caregivers. How will the outcomes of your project benefit the Canadian economy and what progress has your project made in achieving these outcomes?

{$item}

AGE-WELL is expected to have significant benefits to Canadian society through improved quality of life of older adults and their caregivers, health and independence of seniors, improved policy, practice and services. How will the outcomes of your project eventually benefit the Canadian society? Provide any demonstrated evidence of the impact of service or knowledge products on key health and quality of life outcomes relevant to healthy aging.

{$item}

How many products is your project developing?

{$item}

Use the attached supporting documents (AGE-WELL PRL Guidelines), determine the “Product Readiness Level” (PRL) your product(s) currently at:

PRL Levels
  • INNOVATION RESEARCH (PRL 1) basic principles observed
  • INCUBATOR (PRL 2-3) technology concept formulated; experimental proof of concept
  • PROTOTYPE (PRL 4-5) technology validated in lab; technology validated in relevant environment (industrially relevant environment in the case of key enabling technologies)
  • EXPERIMENTAL IMPLEMENTATION (PRL 6-7) technology demonstrated in relevant environment (industrially relevant environment in the case of key enabling technologies); system prototype demonstration in operational environment
  • OUTCOMES (PRL 8-9) system complete and qualified; actual system proven in operational environment (competitive manufacturing in the case of key enabling technologies; or in space)

{$item}

ReportSection.name: Networking/Partnerships
ReportSection.title: Networking and Partnerships
ReportSection.ReportItem:
AGE-WELL Network is expected to demonstrate that the projects have brought together the key individuals and organizations needed to generate and implement multifaceted solutions to the complex challenges it is designed to address. It should be built on relationships with partners and the receptor community that will accelerate the activities, outcomes and impact of the project.

  • the social innovations to be implemented as a result of the Network  and the extent to which these will contribute to more effective public policy in Canada;
  • effective collaboration with the private, public and not-for-profit sectors in technology, market development, and public policy development;
  • the extent to which the Network will help the partners develop strong receptor capacity to exploit current and future research breakthroughs;

Review scorecard

Please provide any additional details needed to support the information in the table below, including justification for categories that have not been completed.

ReportSection.tooltip: Knowledge and Technology Exchange and Exploitation - Knowledge mobilization & Commercialization
ReportSection.name: Knowledge Mobilization
ReportSection.title: Knowledge and Technology Exchange and Exploitation - Knowledge mobilization & Commercialization
ReportSection.ReportItem: NCE Networks are expected to generate social and economic benefits by ensuring the rapid flow of knowledge, ideas and innovations from researchers to Canadian receptors. Projects are expected to demonstrate that the appropriate activities will be undertaken and the appropriate resources allocated to maximize those benefits through effective stakeholder engagement and communication.

ReportSection.name: HQP Training
ReportSection.ReportItem: Training is expected to add value to the formal training initiatives already available through the academic community and should aim at helping HQP find employment in the Canadian economy, particularly in sectors related to technology and aging. HQP should be directly involved in the range of activities in a multi-disciplinary team research project and should work closely with industry and community partners and be involved in collaborating within the Age-Well research network and partner universities.

Review scorecard

ReportSection.name: PRL Justifications
ReportSection.title: PRL Justifications & Case Studies
ReportSection.ReportItem:
Use the information you have filled out above to give a justification for the PRL that you have selected including progress made over the past year from one level to the next. If you have not progressed to another PRL provide justification for why

{$item}

Which PRL level do you expect to be at in one year from now? Provide a brief justification and key steps you will be taking to move to the next level

{$item}

Please provide a short case study of outstanding work or achievement in any of the above evaluation impact areas (Scientific Excellence, Networking and Partnerships, Knowledge Mobilization, Commercialization and HQP Training). Case studies provide an opportunity for a better understanding of the work being completed and its impact in the real world. These stories are a great opportunity to promote the amazing work being accomplished within AGE-WELL. (OPTIONAL)

{$item}

ReportSection.name: Review
ReportSection.ReportItem: {$item}
